bio: Shashank Manohar is an Indian politician and former cricket administrator who served as the president of the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) from 2008 to 2015. He was also the president of the Indian National Congress (INC) from 2013 to 2017. Manohar was born on October 23, 1948, in Bharatpur, Rajasthan. He studied law at the University of Rajasthan and later practiced as a lawyer in Delhi. Manohar began his political career in the 1980s, when he was elected to the Rajasthan Legislative Assembly. He served as the state's Law Minister from 1985 to 1989 and was later elected to the Lok Sabha, the lower house of the Indian Parliament. Manohar was also the president of the Indian Olympic Association from 2009 to 2011. In 2013, he was elected as the president of the INC, the largest political party in India. He served in this role until 2017, when he stepped down due to health reasons. Manohar is known for his contributions to Indian cricket and politics. He is also known for his commitment to the development of cricket in India and for his efforts to promote the game globally.

bio: Osama bin Laden was born on March 10, 1957, in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. He was the son of a wealthy construction magnate. He attended college in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, and received a degree in civil engineering. After college, he worked as a construction engineer for his father's company. In 1984, he founded the Islamic Salvation Front, a political party that advocated for the establishment of an Islamic state in Algeria. The party was banned in 1989, and bin Laden fled to Afghanistan, where he joined the mujahideen fighting against the Soviet Union. He became a leader of the mujahideen, and in 1988, he formed al-Qaeda, an organization dedicated to fighting against the United States and its allies. In 1996, bin Laden issued a fatwa, or religious decree, calling for the killing of Americans anywhere in the world. This fatwa was later used as justification for the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks on the United States. Bin Laden was killed by U.S. forces in Pakistan on May 2, 2011.

She also worked to promote cultural and artistic exchanges between Iran and the rest of the world.
